tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving work rate and time. It requires multiple steps to solve, including calculating the remaining work and determining the required robot power. The multi-step reasoning and the need to understand work-rate concepts make it a medium-hard problem.

answer_validation.reasoning: Treat total work as proportional to robot-hours. Initially: 125 robots, 7 h/day, 52 days. Total planned robot-hours: 125 \times 7 \times 52 = 45500 robot-hours. After 39 days, work done is \frac{5}{7} of total, so remaining work is \frac{2}{7} of total. Work completed in 39 days: 125 \times 7 \times 39 = 34125 robot-hours. This should equal \frac{5}{7} of total work W. Let W be in robot-hours at 7 h/day baseline. From proportion: \frac{5}{7}W = 34125 \Rightarrow W = 34125 \times \frac{7}{5} = 47775 robot-hours. Then remaining work = W - 34125 = 13650 robot-hours. Remaining time: 52 - 39 = 13 days, with each robot now working 8 h/day. If R is the total number of robots in the remaining period, total remaining capacity = R \times 8 \times 13 = 104R robot-hours. Set equal to remaining work: 104R = 13650 \Rightarrow R = 131.25 robots. Initially there are 125 robots, so additional robots required = 131.25 - 125 = 6.25. Since number of robots must be an integer, the minimal feasible integer is 7, but none of the options (50, 89, 146, 175) match 6, 7, or any reasonable rounding. Alternative interpretations (e.g., assuming total work fixed by initial plan: 45500 robot-hours) also lead to non-integer or non-option answers. Hence the official key awarded marks to all, indicating the options are inconsistent with any sensible interpretation. Therefore, 'Marks to All' is correct as per official GATE decision.

step_by_step: Step 1: Define work in terms of robot-hours. One robot working 1 hour does 1 unit of work. Total planned work if plan was followed: 125 robots \times 7 h/day \times 52 days = 45500 robot-hours.
Step 2: Compute work actually done in 39 days: 125 robots \times 7 h/day \times 39 days = 34125 robot-hours. This is given to be \frac{5}{7} of total work W.
Step 3: Use proportion to find total work W: \frac{5}{7}W = 34125 \Rightarrow W = 34125 \times \frac{7}{5} = 47775 robot-hours. Then remaining work = W - 34125 = 13650 robot-hours.

Step 4: Remaining time is 52 - 39 = 13 days. Now each robot works 8 h/day. Let R be the total number of robots in this remaining period. Available work capacity = R \times 8 \times 13 = 104R robot-hours.
Step 5: Equate remaining work to remaining capacity: 104R = 13650 \Rightarrow R = 131.25 robots. Additional robots required = R - 125 = 6.25, which is not an integer and does not match any option.

Step 6: Check alternative interpretation (keeping total work as 45500 robot-hours). Then remaining work = 45500 - 34125 = 11375 robot-hours. With 13 days and 8 h/day, if N is additional robots, total robots = 125 + N, so (125 + N) \times 8 \times 13 = 11375 \Rightarrow 104(125 + N) = 11375 \Rightarrow N \approx -16.7, meaning fewer robots would be needed, again not matching options.

Step 7: Since all reasonable interpretations fail to yield any of the given options, the question is flawed. The official GATE key therefore awarded full marks to all candidates, which is why 'Marks to All' is the official outcome.
formulas_used: $\text{Work} = \text{number of robots} \times \text{hours per day} \times \text{number of days}$

topic.name: General aptitude - Work and time (not core AE syllabus)
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE General Aptitude -> Quantitative Aptitude -> Work and Time

essential: Concept of work measured in man-hours or robot-hours
Setting up and solving simple linear equations
Understanding of proportions and fractions of a whole

Main Concept: requires: Understanding that work is proportional to workers \times time
requires: Ability to convert verbal statements into algebraic equations
enables: Solving more complex scheduling and resource allocation problems
enables: Critical evaluation of problem statements for internal consistency

difficulty_factors: Ambiguity/inconsistency in the problem statement makes it tricky
Requires checking that the numerical result matches given options
Involves multi-step proportional reasoning with fractions

textbook_references.author: R.S. Aggarwal
textbook_references.section: Basic problems on work and wages

textbook_references.book: How to Prepare for Quantitative Aptitude for the CAT
textbook_references.author: Arun Sharma

video_references.professor: General aptitude instructor (e.g., Unacademy / NPTEL GA)
video_references.book_reference: Standard QA books on Time and Work
video_references.topic_covered: Time and Work problems using man-hours concept

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Model work in robot-hours \rightarrow Use given fraction to find total work \rightarrow Compute remaining work \rightarrow Equate to remaining capacity with changed hours \rightarrow Solve for robots \rightarrow Compare with options \rightarrow Conclude inconsistency
key_insights: Work in such problems is conveniently expressed in worker-hours (here, robot-hours).
The fraction of work completed allows you to back-calculate total work.
Always verify that your numerical answer matches one of the options; if not, reconsider assumptions or recognize a flawed question.

formulas_principles.name: Work in worker-hours
formulas_principles.conditions: N is number of workers, h is hours per day, d is number of days; work assumed proportional to worker-hours
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relation to compute total work and work done

formulas_principles.name: Proportional work relation
formulas_principles.conditions: Same type of workers with constant efficiency
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates fractions of work done under different worker and time conditions

formulas_principles.name: Fraction of work equation
formulas_principles.conditions: Given that five-seventh of total work equals work done in first phase
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to compute total work from partial work

formulas_principles.name: Remaining work capacity equation
formulas_principles.conditions: R robots, 8 hours per day, 13 days remaining
formulas_principles.relevance: Determines required robots in remaining period

industry_examples: Planning maintenance tasks in an aircraft hangar where number of technicians and shift hours can change over time
Scheduling assembly-line robots in an aerospace manufacturing facility to meet delivery deadlines
specific_systems: Automated riveting robots in aircraft wing assembly lines
Robotic inspection systems for fuselage panels
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of required manpower or robot-hours is critical for meeting project deadlines and controlling costs in aerospace manufacturing and maintenance operations.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming total work is fixed by the initial plan (125 robots, 7 h, 52 days) and ignoring the given information that 5/7 of work was done in 39 days.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They treat the first statement as defining total work and overlook that actual progress may differ from the plan.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always use the fraction-of-work information to compute total work; do not assume the plan was perfectly followed unless explicitly stated.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a different remaining work and wrong number of robots, not matching any option.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that hours per day change from 7 to 8 in the second phase and using 7 hours in both phases.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They rush and miss the change in working hours hidden in the wording.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline all changing quantities (robots, hours/day, days) before starting calculations.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates or overestimates required robots, giving an incorrect answer.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not checking whether the final numerical answer matches any option and forcing a choice that is 'closest'.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Exam pressure leads them to think they must pick one option even if calculations do not match.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: If no option matches, recheck calculations; if still no match, mark the question for review and move on. Recognize that sometimes questions can be flawed.
common_mistakes.consequence: Unnecessary negative marking due to forced guessing on a flawed question.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Work = WNH: Work = Workers \times Number of hours per day \times Hours (days)
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering the relation between work, workers, and time
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when setting up time-and-work problems to ensure all three factors are included.

flashcards.front: In time-and-work problems, what does 'man-hours' or 'robot-hours' represent?
flashcards.back: It represents the total amount of work done, defined as (number of workers) \times (hours worked). Work is assumed proportional to worker-hours when efficiency is constant.

flashcards.front: Write the formula relating work to workers, hours per day, and days.
flashcards.back: Work (in worker-hours) = Number of workers \times Hours per day \times Number of days, i.e., $W = N h d$.

flashcards.front: If 10 robots working 6 h/day finish a job in 5 days, how many robot-hours is the job?
In a two-phase work problem, what must you always check before writing equations?
flashcards.back: Check if the number of workers or hours per day changes between phases, and mark these changes clearly to use correct values in each phase.

flashcards.front: A team completes 3/5 of a job in 12 days. If they keep the same daily capacity, how many total days to finish the job?
flashcards.back: If 3/5 is done in 12 days, full job takes 12 \times (5/3) = 20 days.

real_world_context.application: Scheduling maintenance crews for aircraft checks (A-check, C-check, D-check).
real_world_context.industry_example: If 30 technicians working 8 h/day can complete a C-check in 10 days, planners can estimate how many extra technicians are needed to reduce downtime to 7 days.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation can lead to aircraft being grounded longer than planned, causing financial losses and schedule disruptions.

real_world_context.application: Allocating robots on an aircraft assembly line to meet delivery deadlines.
real_world_context.industry_example: If a wing assembly line with 20 robots working 16 h/day completes 4 wings per week, managers can estimate how many additional robots or hours are needed to increase output to 6 wings per week.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating required capacity can delay deliveries and breach contracts; overestimating wastes capital on underutilized robots.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan for key numbers (workers, hours/day, days, fraction of work). If you can quickly set up work = workers \times hours \times days and a simple proportion, it is a quick 2-mark question.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If your carefully checked answer does not match any option, avoid blind guessing; such questions are sometimes awarded marks to all.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to spend about 2-3 minutes. If algebra becomes messy or inconsistent, mark for review and move on to avoid time sink.

search_keywords: time and work problems robots workers hours
GATE general aptitude time and work 2018
fraction of work completed 5/7 after some days
work and time proportional reasoning examples

alternative_methods.name: Unit work method
alternative_methods.description: Assume total work = 1 unit. Compute daily work rate in each phase as a fraction of the whole job, then use fractions to find remaining work and required workers.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Conceptually clear, keeps numbers small. Cons: Still leads to same inconsistency here because the problem data itself is inconsistent.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in many time-and-work problems where fractions of work are given and you want to avoid large numbers.

alternative_methods.name: Rate comparison method
alternative_methods.description: Compute work rate of one robot per hour, then express all work done and remaining in terms of this base rate, solving for required robots by equating rates.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Emphasizes rate concept; can be intuitive. Cons: Algebraically equivalent to robot-hours approach, so no advantage in flawed questions.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When you are more comfortable thinking in terms of 'job per day' or 'job per hour' rather than total worker-hours.

connections_to_other_subjects.Operations Research: Similar to resource allocation and scheduling problems where you assign workers or machines to tasks under time constraints.
connections_to_other_subjects.Project Management: Relates to critical path analysis and manpower planning to meet project deadlines.
connections_to_other_subjects.Industrial Engineering: Connected to line balancing and capacity planning in manufacturing systems.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Conceptually similar to matching capacity (actuators) to required performance (tracking a desired schedule).

deeper_dive_topics: Stochastic project scheduling with variable worker efficiency
Linear programming formulations of workforce planning
PERT/CPM methods for project time estimation
Sensitivity analysis of project duration to resource changes

question_metadata.success_rate_estimate: Low, due to flawed options; final scoring was Marks to All

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The topic is standard and relevant, but problem statements must be checked carefully to avoid internal inconsistencies that force 'marks to all' decisions.

rag_quality.notes: RAG context was about aerospace topics (flight performance, orbital mechanics, electric propulsion, fatigue, timekeeping) and not about general aptitude time-and-work problems. Solution relied entirely on internal quantitative reasoning, not on RAG.

future_questions_potential: Modify the numbers so that the required additional robots is an integer matching an option, reinforcing correct work-time reasoning.
Ask for the fraction of work remaining after a certain number of days when workers or hours per day change midway.
Introduce variable efficiency (e.g., robots become 10% more efficient later) and ask students to compute new completion time.
Frame a similar problem in an aerospace context, such as number of technicians needed to complete aircraft maintenance before a deadline.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A contract is to be completed in 52 days and 125 identical robots were employed, each operational for 7 hours a day. After 39 days, five-seventh of the work was completed. How many additional robots would be required to complete the work on time, if each robot is now operational for 8 hours a day?
